key_title: Key to the species of Xanthorrhoea

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the genera of Xanthorrhoeaceae

source.author: Conn, B.J.
source.title: Xanthorrhoeaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: Modified from: Conn, B.J. (1994). Xanthorrhoeaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Spike of the inflorescence shorter than or equal to the scape; sepals and the bracts between the flowers usually hairy; stem subterranean or up to 0.6 m high
Spike of the inflorescence longer than the scape; sepals and the bracts between the flowers usually glabrous; stem usually well-developed, up to 5 m high, or sometimes absent
Bracts between the flowers densely hairy on abaxial surface, such that indumentum appears velvety; stem usually up to 0.6 m high, or sometimes absent
Bracts between the flowers glabrous, or if hairy or fringed, then indumentum never velvety; stem subterranean
Leaves 2.3–7.0 mm wide, glaucous or green; scape more than 90 cm long; bracts between flowers narrow-triangular
Leaves 1.9–3.5 mm wide, green; scape usually less than 90 cm long; bracts between flowers triangular
Leaves 5–12 mm wide; stem absent or up to 1 m high
Leaves 1–4 mm wide; stem massive, up to 5 m high
Scape 65–140 cm long; leaves bluish, very glaucous; north of the Great Dividing Range
Scape usually less than 60 cm long; leaves green, occasionally blue or glaucous; mostly south of the Great Dividing Range or west of the Grampians
